Types

Mode = enum
  Unconnected,              ## No levels are propagated in either direction.
  Input,                    ## Levels will propagate from a trace to the pin, but not vice versa.
  Output,                   ## Levels will propagate from the pin to a trace, but not vice versa.
  Bidi                       ## Levels will propagate both from the pin to a trace and vice versa.
The direction in which levels are propagated through the pin. 
Pin = ref object
  number: int ## The pin number. This is normally defined in chip or port 
              ## literature.
  name: string ## The pin name. Again, this is normally defined in chip or 
               ## port literature.
  trace: Trace ## The trace to which this pin is connected. Will be `nil` 
               ## if the pin has not been connected to a trace. Once a 
               ## trace has been connected, there is no way to disconnect
               ## it (physical pins don't generally change their traces
               ## either).
  mode: Mode ## The mode of the pin, a description of which direction 
             ## data is propagating through it.
  pull: Pull ## The level that the pin will take if its level is set to 
             ## `NaN`. This value is set by `pullUp`, `pullDown`, and
             ## `pullOff`
  level: float ## The level of the pin. If the pin has no level (i.e., it's
               ## disconnected or in a hi-Z state), this will be `NaN`.
  listeners: seq[Pin -> void] ## A list of listener functions that get invoked, in order,
                              ## 
                              ## when the pin's level is changed by its connected trace.
  connected: bool            ## Whether or not the pin has a connected trace.

A pin on an IC package or a port.

This is the sole interface between these devices and the outside world. Pins have a mode, which indicates whether they're used by their chip/port for input, output, both, or neither; and a level, which is the signal present on them. In digital circuits, this is generally 0 or 1, though there's no reason a pin can't work with analog signals (and thus have any level at all).

Pins may also be pulled up or down, which defines what level they have if a level isn't given to them. This emulates the internal pull-ups and pull-downs that some chips have (such as the port pins on a 6526 CIA). If no level is given to them and they have no pull-up or pull-down, then their level will be NaN, or no level at all. This can be used to represent, e.g., a high-impedance state that cuts the pin off from its circuit.

Pins and traces are intimately linked, which is why both are defined in this file. A pin can be associated with exactly one trace, and unless the pin's level is NaN and it is an output pin, the pin and the trace will have the same level. (It follows then that all of the other pins connected to that trace will also have that level.) If their levels do not match, then one is changed to match the other. If the pin is an output pin, it will define the mutual level. If it's an input pin, the trace will define the level. If the pin is bidirectional, the level will be the level of the trace if it is connected to other non-bidirectional, non-null output pins; otherwise, whatever was set last will prevail.

A pin may also have one or more listeners registered to it. The listener(s) will be invoked if the level of the pin changes because of a change to its trace's level. No listener will be invoked if the level of the pin is merely set programmatically. This means that only input and bidirectional pins will invoke listeners, though output pins may also register them, since it is possible that the output pin will become a different kind of pin later.

Trace = ref object
  pins: seq[Pin]             ## A list of all of the pins that are connected to this trace.
  pull: Pull ## The level that the trace will take if its level is set to `NaN` and 
             ## there are no output pins with levels that will override this. This
             ## value is set by `pullUp`, `pullDown`, and `pullOff`.
  level: float ## The level of the trace. If the trace has no level (i.e., it has no 
               ## output pins with levels and has had its own level set to `NaN`), this
               ## will be `NaN`.

A printed-circuit board trace that connects two or more pins.

A trace is designed primarily to have its level modified by a connected output pin. However, the level can also be set directly (this is often useful in testing and debugging). When a trace's level is set directly, its actual value is chosen according to the following rules:

  1. If the trace has at least one output pin connected to it that has a level, the trace takes on the maximum level among all of its connected output pins.
  2. If the value being set is None: a. If the trace has been pulled up, its value is 1.0. b. If the trace has been pulled down, its value is 0.0. c. Its value is None.
  3. The trace takes on the set value.

If a trace is set by a pin (either by an output pin changing values or by an unconnected pin mode-changing into an output pin), then the value is simply set unless the value it's being set to is None. In that case the same rules as direct setting apply.

A change in the level of the trace will be propagated to any input pins connected to

the trace. When this happens, the observers of all of those input pins are notified
of the change.

Procs

proc isInput(mode: Mode): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether a mode is an input mode; i.e., whether it is Input or Bidi. 
proc isOutput(mode: Mode): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether a mode is an output mode; i.e., whether it's Output or Bidi. 
proc number(pin: Pin): int {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
The pin's number. This is the physical location of a pin on its chip's package. 
proc name(pin: Pin): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
The pin's name. This is generally provided by the device's literature. 
proc high(pin: Pin): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin is high. While this generally means a value of 1, any value of 0.5 or higher will be considered "high". 
proc low(pin: Pin): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin is low. While this generally means a value of 0, any value less than 0.5 will be considered "low". 
proc floating(pin: Pin): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin's level is floating. This is represented by a value of NaN and indicates that a pin is in a high-impedence state. 
proc high(trace: Trace): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the trace is high. While this generally means a value of 1, any value of 0.5 or higher will be considered "high" 
proc low(trace: Trace): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the trace is low. While this generally means a value of 0, any value less than 0.5 will be considered "low". 
proc floating(trace: Trace): bool {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin's level is floating. This is represented by a value of NaN and indicates that a trace has no level at all because no output pins are driving it. 
proc level(pin: Pin): float {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns the pin's current level. 
proc level=(pin: Pin; level: float) {...}{.raises: [Exception], tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. Otherwise, any connected trace is also updated with the new level. 
proc level(trace: Trace): float {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns the trace's current level. 
proc level=(trace: Trace; level: float) {...}{.raises: [Exception],
    tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's level. This setting will be overidden if the trace has other output pins connected to it or if it has been pulled up or down. 
proc set(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                          tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to 1. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. 
proc clear(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                            tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to 0. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. 
proc float(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                            tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to NaN. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. If the pin has been pulled up or down, it will take on the level associated with that pull instead. 
proc set(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to 1. This will only have an effect if no higher-leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc clear(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                  tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to 0. This will only have an effect if no higher-leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc float(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                  tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to NaN. This will only have an effect if no leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc `+`(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                          tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to 1. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. 
proc `-`(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                          tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to 0. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. 
proc `~`(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                          tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's level to NaN. This will have no effect if the pin's mode is Input and if the pin is connected to a trace. If the pin has been pulled up or down, it will take on the level associated with that pull instead. 
proc `+`(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to 1. This will only have an effect if no higher-leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc `-`(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to 0. This will only have an effect if no higher-leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc `~`(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, inline, raises: [Exception],
                                tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace's value to NaN. This will only have an effect if no leveled output pins are connected to the trace. 
proc toggle(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, raises: [Exception],
                             tags: [RootEffect].}
Toggles the pin's level. This will treat that level as digital; if it is "high" (0.5 or over), the pin will be set to 0, and if it's "low" (less than 0.5), the pin will be set to 1. This has no effect on pins with NaN levels. 
proc mode(pin: Pin): Mode {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns the pin's current mode. 
proc mode=(pin: Pin; mode: Mode) {...}{.raises: [Exception], tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the pin's mode. This will also account for the values that the pin and its connected trace might take on because of the new mode. 
proc isInput(pin: Pin): bool {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin is in an input mode; i.e., whether it is Input or Bidi. 
proc isOutput(pin: Pin): bool {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Determines whether the pin is in an output mode; i.e., whether it is Output or Bidi. 
proc addListener(pin: Pin; listener: Pin -> void): Pin {...}{.discardable,
    raises: [], tags: [].}
Adds a new listener function to the list of listeners that the pin will call when its trace updates it. If the function is already in the list, it will not be added a second time. 
proc removeListener(pin: Pin; listener: Pin -> void): Pin {...}{.discardable,
    raises: [Exception], tags: [RootEffect].}
Removes the provided listener function from the list of listeners that the pin will call when its trace updates it. If the listener is already not in this list, this function will do noting. 
proc pullUp(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, raises: [], tags: [].}
Sets the pin to be pulled up. This pin will then take on a level of 1 any time its level is set to NaN. 
proc pullDown(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, raises: [], tags: [].}
Sets the pin to be pulled down. This pin will then take on a level of 0 any time its level is set to NaN. 
proc pullOff(pin: Pin): Pin {...}{.discardable, raises: [], tags: [].}
Removes any pull status from the pin. The pin will then take on a level of NaN if it is set to that level. 
proc pullUp(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, raises: [Exception],
                                   tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace to be pulled up. This trace will then take on a level of 1 any time its level is set to NaN. 
proc pullDown(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, raises: [Exception],
                                     tags: [RootEffect].}
Sets the trace to be pulled down. This trace will then take on a level of 0 any time its level is set to NaN. 
proc pullOff(trace: Trace): Trace {...}{.discardable, raises: [Exception],
                                    tags: [RootEffect].}
Removes any pull status from the trace. The trace will then take on a level of NaN if it is set to that level. 
proc addPin(trace: Trace; pin: Pin): Trace {...}{.discardable, raises: [Exception],
    tags: [RootEffect].}
Adds a pin to the ones connected by the trace. If the pin is already connected to a trace (including to this one), this function will do nothing. 
proc addPins(trace: Trace; pins: varargs[Pin]): Trace {...}{.discardable,
    raises: [Exception], tags: [RootEffect].}
Adds one or more pins to the ones connected by the trace. If any of these pins is already connected to a trace (including this one), the add will not happen for that pin. 
proc newPin(number: int; name: string; mode: Mode = Unconnected): Pin {...}{.
    raises: [Exception], tags: [RootEffect].}
Creates a new Pin. This pin will start with a level of NaN and no pull. 
proc newTrace(pins: varargs[Pin]): Trace {...}{.raises: [Exception],
    tags: [RootEffect].}
Creates a new Trace from a sequence of the pins that should be connected to the new trace. This trace will start with no pull and a level defined by the output pins in the pin sequence.
